folder: Buhrman's Lane & St. Mark's Avenue, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - St. Mark's Avenue
text:
Alley Park: Buhrman's Lane, east and north side, as seen from some point in Alley Pond, showing from left to right the home of W.C. Buhrman and the general store. This is a set of three views from slightly different angles.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

1922.

folder: Buhrman's Lane & St. Mark's Avenue, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - St. Mark's Avenue
text:
Alley Park: Alley Road, east side, north of Buhrman's Lane, showing the Foster house in 1873. "James Hedger, apparently ran the later Buhrman Mill in 1782 and lived with his sister the Widow Talman in this home on the Alley, opposite the mill. Here he was attacked by a number of soldiers of the 38th and 54th Regiments, then lying at Flushing, and killed. Two were captured, tried at Bedford Long Island and executed." It is doubtful but some state that the first floor was erected in 1663 and the second story added in 1777. "Schmidt 1777" is carved on one of the rafters. This is a set of four views.

1922.
Views 1, 3 & 4.
View 2: April 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Alley Park East & Grand Central Parkway, Queens, NY
text:
Alley Park: Alley Park East (Alley Road), west side, north of the Grand Central Parkway (about one fourth of a mile north of Cedar Lane, also known as Black Stump Road). This set of two views shows the R. Cathcart house from 1860-1891. It is now a part of Alley Park.

folder: Alley Road & Buhrman's Lane, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Alley Road - Buhrman's Lane
text:
Alley Park: Alley Road, east side, north of Buhrman's Lane, showing in a set of three views the Foster house. It was erected in 1776. The stone part of this house erected in the same year was used in that year as the Queens County Jail for Federal prisoners. T. Foster owned it in 1891. In 1909 the Cord Meyer Company had it. It is no longer in existence in 1937. If one were to place it on a late map it would probably be in the Horace Harding Boulevard at Alley Park East. This is a set of three views showing the rear of the house.

April 1926.
Views 2 & 3: 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Buhrman's Lane & West Alley Road, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - West Alley Road
text:
Alley Park: Buhrman Lane (Horace Harding Boulevard), north side, between West Alley Road (left) and Alley Park East (right). Buhrman Lane is seen at its junction with Buhrman Lane on the N.W. side of Alley Pond. This is a set of two views from slightly different angles. The structure shown, erected in 1828, is stated by some newspapers to be the first Post Office in the town. The same being transferred to Flushing Village when Broadway was constructed and traffic diverted to the new road. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Alley Park East & 53rd Terrace, Queens, NY
text:
Alley Park: Alley Creek southwest from pumping station located on the east bank of Alley Creek opposite Alley Park East at 53rd Terrace, showing in the background a cut into Alley Pond. Also seen is the top of M. Buhrman's Mill. The house at the left is either the Cord Mayer Co. house or the F. W. Buhrman house. All this view has now been converted into Alley Park by the City of New York.

June 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Alley Park East & West Alley Drive, Queens, NY
text:
Alley Park: Alley Park East (Alley Road), north to West Alley Drive (West Alley Road), showing in center of view the W.J. Bennett house of 1850. At the left foreground is a view of A.C. Hyatts house of 1873. By 1909, W.C. and F.W. Buhrman acquired possession of practically all land east and west of Alley Park East and south of Alley Pond. In 1937 this property was converted into Alley Park and the North Hills Golf Club. This is a set of two views.

January 1925.
View 2: 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Alley Park East & Grand Central Parkway, Queens, NY
text:
(1)

Alley Park: Alley Park East (formerly Alley Road.), west side, north, about 1000 feet, of the Grand Central Parkway (formerly Black Stump Road, Black Road and Cedar Lane.) In 1873 the house was occupied by R. Cathcart. In 1909 the property was owned by W.C. Buhrman. In 1937 it formed a part of Alley Park, belonging to the Greater City of New York.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing Alley Road (now 1937 Alley Park East), continuing northward from R. Cathcart's house.

Eugene L. Armbruster.
January 1925.

folder: Alley Park East & Buhrman's Lane, Queens, NY
text:
Alley Park: Alley Park East, just north of its junction with Buhman Lane, showing the Platt Carll house, erected in 1776. Some of the occupants are: Widow Talman, 1782; J.P. Carll, 1846; T. Foster, 1860; Miss Foster, 1873; T. Foster, 1891-1896. In 1909 it was owned by the Cord Meyer Company. This is a set of three views from different angles.

January 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Queens: Alley Park East - Buhrman's Lane

title: Queens: Alley Park East - Buhrman's Lane

folder: Buhrman's Lane & Alley Road, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - Alley Road
text:
(1) Alley Park: Burhmans Lane, north side, as seen looking north-west from Alley Road (now, 1937, Alley Park East), showing a group of old buildings belonging to W.C. Buhrman in 1873. In the foreground on the east side of the pond's outlet to Alley Creek and partially submerged is the "Old Mill" said to have been erected in 1752. Beyond it is the general store erected in 1828. In the last house, lived a blacksmith. The map of 1873 shows this house to belong also to W.C. Buhrman. The mill was demolished by fire in 1926. In 1828 the general store and mill were acquired by Benjamin P. Loverre of Flushing, who at that time also owned the old Flushing Hotel, and in 1858 Wm. C. Buhrman took possession and conducted it until 1898. His son, Wm. W. Buhrman, operated both the mill and the general store from 1898 to 1914. The Alley Pond Corporation was the owner in 1926.

January 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, showing only a close up of the mill.

January 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3) The same.

January 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

In the last house, lived a blacksmith. The map of 1873 shows this house to belong also to W.C. Buhrman. The mill was demolished by fire in 1926. In 1828 the general store and mill were acquired by Benjamin P. Loverre of Flushing, who at that time also owned the old Flushing Hotel, and in 1858 Wm. C. Buhrman took possession and conducted it until 1898. His son, Wm. W. Buhrman, operated both the mill and the general store from 1898 to 1914. The Alley Pond Corporation was the owner in 1926.

folder: Buhrman's Lane & West Alley Road, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - West Alley Road
text:
Alley Park: Buhrman Lane, west side, between West Alley Road (left) and the Horace Harding Boulevard (right), showing, a structure that is said to have been the original Flushing Post Office. This was the original Buhrman house in the Alley and is south of the present home.

January 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Buhrman's Lane & Horace Harding Boulevard, Queens, NY
original_title: Queens: Buhrman's Lane - Horace Harding Boulevard
text:
Alley Park: Buhrman Lane, west side, south of Horace Harding Boulevard, showing the home of W.C. Buhrman. This house was built about 1905. The old home stood just north (foreground) of the present house, against the stone wall. The original postoffice is said to be the little yellow house south of the present home (testimony of Mrs. Foster given about 1900). She was born about 1812. The other yellow house south of the Post Office, was the poor house of this district. This is a set of two views.

January 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Buhrman's Lane & Horace Harding Boulevard, Queens, NY

January 1926.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
